subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Digest Number 528
msgSnippet: ... All diphthongs to me: skway-er nee-er kyoo-er So is the ay : eh-ii Even the y sound is actually a squished merger (diphthong?): (ih)-(eh) The same is
messageBody:
On 10. Nov.,`07, at 03:22 EST, Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com wrote:

> SQUARE Et + Roe Eight + Roe
> NEAR It + Roe Eat + Roe
> CURE Foot + Roe Ooze + Roe

All diphthongs to me:

skway-er
nee-er
kyoo-er

So is the "ay":
eh-ii

Even the "y" sound is actually a "squished" merger (diphthong?):
(ih)-(eh)

The same is true for "w":
oo-{puff-of-air-through-lips}-(uh):

Thus, 2 of the above "simple" words are actually:

square=
sk--[oo-{puff-of-air-through-lips}--(uh)]-[eh-ii]--[(ih)-(eh)]--er

cure=
k--[(ih)-(eh)]--oo--er

So, should diphthongs be treated as single letters (vowels, as OT does with long-a, and the voiced consonants "w" & "y"), or as their underlying sounds?
Since simplicity in writing leads to vowel-treatment, that seems preferable. However, that does lead back to "arbitrary" choices about _which_ mergers to treat as "single" elements, and which to reflect as separate-but-conjoined sounds...

On 10. Nov.,`07, at 03:22 EST, Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com wrote:

> > SQUARE Et + Roe Eight + Roe
> > NEAR It + Roe Eat + Roe
> > CURE Foot + Roe Ooze + Roe


All diphthongs to me:

skway-er
nee-er
kyoo-er

So is the "ay":
eh-ii

Even the "y" sound is actually a "squished" merger (diphthong?):
(ih)-(eh)

The same is true for "w":
oo-{puff-of-air-through-lips}-(uh):

Thus, 2 of the above "simple" words are actually:

square=
sk--[oo-{puff-of-air-through-lips}--(uh)]-[eh-ii]--[(ih)-(eh)]--er

cure=
k--[(ih)-(eh)]--oo--er

So, should diphthongs be treated as single letters (vowels, as OT does  
with long-a, and the voiced consonants "w" & "y"), or as their  
underlying sounds?
Since simplicity in writing leads to vowel-treatment, that seems  
preferable. However, that does lead back to "arbitrary" choices about  
_which_ mergers to treat as "single" elements, and which to reflect as  
separate-but-conjoined sounds...
